review_title: VR as it has to be
one_reviews_text:
This game will really take you into space. The devs made it possible to nearly "feel" the zero gravity through the excellent movement of yourself and all the sorroundings.
But not only the very very excellent movement is a point to have a look at, also the story got me from the very beginning till the end. And everything on a level where you don't get simply scared to death or you need to become ultra hectically.
I really liked the sense of humor and interaction between Cpt. Rhodes and Jack. It make me smile many times and I really cannot wait for the second part to be released! 

This is the way vr should be handled!

With this game it’s an experience of bond and mystery finding the mystery and the story is amazing without picking up a gun with you solving problems on the Saturn base on Kronos 2 space ship and the ending was the only thing that made me cry on a piece of media

It is one of the best looking and feeling VR games for sure! My least favourite thing was navigation but you get used to it. Aside from that, a superb experience! Up there with Half-Life: Alyx imo. (played via Oculus Link on Oculus Quest)

Really one of the best games on VR. I enjoyed every minute of playing. Six and a half hours, yes a little shorter game time but I wasn't bored for a minute :)
It never occurred to me that a 3-year-old game can match HL: Alyx and that's proof that when you're giving someone a job, it can be worth it and you don't even need weapons :)
Perfect graphics. Body tracking mastered at one.
Brilliant story (I was really worried about Olivia that something would happen to her and leave me alone in the empty universe)
I can't wait for the second part. Good work Ready at Dawn !!

review_title: My real live work is more interesting...
one_reviews_text: ...Than Lone Echos gameplay. Whole time I was just, do I really have to do all these boring chores again and again. Even hyped story is the most gereric scifi-story I can think of. I give one extra star from trying to make proper VR-game.

review_title: Hope for the future of VR
one_reviews_text: So many VR games are really just showcases of VR technology that lack any real soul. Don't get me wrong, I LOOOVE hacking people up in Blade & Sorcery and I still play it all the time, but VR as a medium should be the closest we get to true immersion, and games like Beat Saber and B&S just don't really go that deep. I've been losing faith in the VR industry for this reason, but Lost Echo has provided hope for the future. I've never been so immersed in a video game. Never truly lost myself so much in a story and character. Jack provided all of that and more. I was no longer just a dude swinging my arms around with a headset on my face. I was floating in space, repairing satellites and space ships, bouncing around in Zero G, cracking wise with my human counterpart, tapping the side of my head to activate my flashlight and traverse dark tunnels and asteroids. THIS is the VR experience I've always wanted. THIS is the reason I bought a VR headset so long ago. I can't believe I only discovered it a couple of days ago. I truly hope the future of VR is more Lost Echo and less Gorn. I can't wait to play through again once I update my graphics card! I played on a 970 so I knew it wouldn't be gorgeous, but even on low settings, I was stunned.
review_feedback: Hey there, thanks for taking the time to share your honest feedback with us. We're happy to hear you loved playing Lone Echo :)!

review_title: WTF Great Start W Grave Limit
one_reviews_text:
VERY tempted to give this one star because I'm so irritated by its shortcoming but the fact is most of it is really quite excellent.  The problem:  everythig you have to do requires an NPC to tell you to do it.  The problem is, sometimes the cue just never comes.  Since you can't do things except in a specific order, once you get to one of these unspoken cues, the rest of the game is unreachable.  I was able to get most of the garden going again but being unable to get a cue to open the panel, I have no idea what the rest of the game is like.

Still, it was really cool up to that point.  Having done the garden two dozen times now wishing I could open the panel, guess I just got ripped off on this one.  :-(

God where do I start. The scenery is amazing, the story is amazing, and is the perfect combination of difficult, and intriguing it makes you beat it in one sitting, like I did. If you are looking for a game with a good storyline, AND good graphics, this is the game you are looking for. It is definitely worth the price.

This game is an amazing, detailed, in depth way to experience true 0G. I have played this game start to finish wanting more. When the story ended, I was waiting for more as I wasn't ready for a finish. The Game is rather short however I was immersed from the get go after donning my headset. 5 *****, would love to see a Prequel or Sequel of this. Very good indeed.

I was also not sure if I wanted to buy this or not, as I suffer from slight Motion sickness from games like Boneworks and other like this. However I played for hours and didn't feel ill at all. (I DO RECOMMEND PLAY ECHO VR FIRST TO TEST YOUR VR SPACE-LEGS) 

I'm not gonna lie. I think this game is gonna struggle to get very many review's less than 5 Star. 

Well done to all of the development team!

review_title: This is what the true potential of VR is
one_reviews_text: Absolutely fantastic game. One of the best, if not the best VR game I have played to date. I felt for the characters, was completely immersed, and wanted more after the game ended. Truly a work of art.

I very rarely take the time to write reviews but felt I had to for this one.  I've literally just finished the game as I type this, and it is without doubt the most amazing VR experience I've ever had.  The characters and the voice acting were superb, the environment was utterly convincing, the zero-G movement was easy to get used to and didn't cause any motion sickness (which is unusual for me).  It was challenging, but not *too* challenging.  Great puzzles, excellent story.  I really cannot speak highly enough of this game.

Hope the sequel doesn't take too long to arrive because I want more!!!
Quite simply the best game I've played. I upgraded my PC to be able to play AAA PCVR games (via Oculus Link), and this alone was enough to make it all worth it :) Can't wait for the sequal!

review_title: The best single player VR game there is
one_reviews_text: This is hands down the best single player game on the oculus store in terms of story line and graphics. I played wirelessly on the quest and it is an incredible experience without being tethered. Well worth the money!

OK dont ever do reviews but ive been playing vr for just over 3 years now and this is in my top 5 for games ive ever played great immersion and well thought out. It is games like this why i can not go back to flat screen games. Vr is great and with developers banging out AAA games like this, is such a great sign of things to come. There is not many games for that money which stand up to this quality i was blown away seeing it nearly came out over 2 and a half years ago. They have my money for part 2 cant wait well done. Its game like this which will show people VR is the way forward dont play the game be in it.
review_feedback: Hey there, thanks for taking the time to share your experience playing Lone Echo with us.

review_title: Fully fleshed, pretty game with great VA
one_reviews_text:
Played on Quest using Link.

This is a really pretty game compared to other VR games/experiences (especially considering its age). 

The story is fairly interesting, but the characters are really well written/acted and interesting. I definitely felt emotionally invested towards the end. 

The game play is smooth but I occasionally found myself in a position were I wasn't sure what to do next. I didn't bother picking up collectibles as a result and I don't think I'd go back for another playthrough. 

It's a little slow for me in places, but it works for the setting and it's very enjoyable if you can get into the right mindset. 

Looking forward to Lone Echo 2.
You really should spent 40$ on this. Its one of the best VR games and if you like space you will like it even more. Im really excited for Lone Echo 2

Thanks to the recent update allowing us to use the charging cable for link and after playing Echo Arena VR beta on Quest, I thought I might try Lone Echo to see how this zero-G playstyle works in an adventure rather than just a sport. Wow! I finished the game in 4 days and loved every minute of it. I am already halfway through my second play through and found some nice easter eggs and took the time to finish the Comsat mission. I often just look around while floating in space and simply cannot believe how I feel like I am really there in an astroid field next to Saturn. This game has made so many of my dreams feel like they are coming true.

I played LE with my older Quest1 mostly wireless with the use of Virtual Desktop (VD). The graphics and performance are mostly good with graphics being a little fuzzy when I am in motion or only fuzzy off in the distance when I stand still. However when I play wired with a normal cable, the graphics and performance is outstanding no matter if moving or not.

My PC specs are:
i7-6700K CPU @ 4.0 GHz (8 cpus), 16gb ram
Nvidia GeForce RTX 2070 8gb vram
Windows Pro 64 bit, DirectX 12

My current ranking of all time favorite "adventure style" VR games:
1) Outer Wilds (using the excellent Nomai-VR mod)
2) Lone Echo I
3) Skyrim VR (with about 12 mods)
4) Karnage Chronicles
5) Half-Life Alex

I have to say on my 2nd play through of this game I have decided it is my favorite VR title so far. Graphics are amazing and the whole concept is very well suited for VR. The enviroments are very immersive and encourage exporation with set pieces That are both believable and very well art directed.  I Have struggled to find a VR title with the right Vibe given the current state of the world but this one delivers if you are a sci fi fan like me.  Hats off to the developers and I really look forward to part 2.  Keep up the great work!

No doubt this game is amazing. 
Great graphics.
Great story.
Cliff hangers.
Real connection to the characters.
Mechanics are simple but done perfect.

I didn't buy this game for a while i just got it ive had vr for about 1.5/2 years now and decided to get the game as there is a LOT of hype around it and the new one coming. I'm happy that i bought it, now i know why there is so much hype around it. You get a real connection to the characters i have not had a game like that since Telltale the walking dead series. The zero g flying around is great!
It's if titanfall turned into a vr game.

The only reason i didn't put a 5 star is because of the price.. It's a two year old game i would have been a lot happier if the game was a little cheaper maybe £20/25.

Cant wait for lone echo 2. Games from these devs will be on my radar from now on! :)
review_feedback: Hey there, thanks for taking the time to share your experience playing Lone Echo with us!

review_title: One of the best VR games on the market.
one_reviews_text: I avoided this game for almost a year now and I regret it! This game is way better than I thought it would be, honestly the feeling of zero gravity is awsome. The story is amazing aswell, please dont make my mistake! Buy this game you wont regret it!

Just finished this game, I took my time as I don't like to rush. Really enjoyed it and looking forward to the next installment. Its amazing me just how many people it takes to create this the credits go on for ever. Just how do you guys organize who does what and when....well done, really loved the look of this game and the physics are fab. Love it...
review_feedback: Thank you for sharing your honest feedback with us. We're happy to hear you loved the game.

one_reviews_text: Boring and crashes constantly.
review_feedback: We’re sorry to hear you’re having issues with crashing. The most common crashes can be resolved by uninstalling/reinstalling the game, checking if your PC has overclocking on, and checking if the game is being blocked by your antivirus or other software. If you’re still having issues, our team would be happy to help you troubleshoot in the Lone Echo Support channel of the community Discord 😊

one_reviews_text:
[PL]
https://youtu.be/nT4Q4MIBGeE?t=16
My computer cannot run games like Half-Life Alyx but I wanted a high quality vr game. This game blew me away. I think it is the best vr game I have played.

This is what VR is supposed to be about!! With so many gimmicky games out there, its no wonder VR hasn't taken off the way we expected it to. However, if just a few more games of this quality are released, I think VR will take over as the next gaming medium. This is truly a triple A title that rivals all of the current games out now, 2 years later.

Lone Echo is extremely immersive down to every little scratch and worn edge of the environment. The concept of embodying a sentient robot to help your human companion through space survival is both exhilarating and existential. The plot is really good and you feel a real bond with your human counterpart, Olivia.

The puzzles are just challenging enough to keep you engaged without beeing overly frustrating and the environment is inexplicably beautiful! 

Seriously, if you have the hardware to run it, just buy it!!! Like now! You won't be disappointed!

Can't wait for Lone Echo 2. Devs, if your second installment is anywhere near as good as this one, just shut up and take my money!

review_title: Top Notch Game But Low Audio Levels
one_reviews_text: Lone Echo is by far the best VR game out there. The graphics are highly detailed and after a while you actually believe you are on a space ship. It is amazing to be able to float from point A to B smoothly and effortlessly. The puzzles are interesting and creative; challenging but not impossible to solve. Olivia is a great companion and her movements are stunningly life like. Once you exit the ship and actually float in outer space, you can see it's a really big, detailed ship you can explore from the outside. The experience is mind boggling. The only defect in the game is that the audio levels are uniformly too low even with the volume at 100%. I have other Oculus Rift S games where the audio is plenty loud. But in Lone Echo I have to strain to hear Olivia. It would be great if the audio in Lone Echo II was normalized (i.e. made as loud as possible). You can always turn it down, but if it is too low the only option is to wear earphones or earbuds- the former interferes with the headset, and the latter may fall out of your ears. Neither is a good alternative.

review_title: Missing arm cant progress through game
one_reviews_text: im currently at the primary digsite putting together a labor unit and one arm is missing cant find it anywhere and when restarting its still does nothing just brings me back to the same save point. i wont restart the whole game just for this one bug would rather not play.

one_reviews_text: Just everything about this game is amazing, the visuals the locomotion and the story every aspect was amazing and done perfectly

This game deserves sooo much publicity !
Complete immersion, incredible esthetic, very good story, brilliant dialogues... and a gameplay that really gives credit to what VR is supposed to be. Moving around in zero gravity is a complete different experience ! Besides the level design is brilliant : not only you can go practically wherever you want but the gameplay itself is very rich : cut, scan, move objects, control your speed, your light, adjust your shield, choose your answers when asked... This was awesome really !
6-7 hours to finish the game for me : this is good, this is a real AAA VR game.
Lone Echo 2 is day 1 for me, absolutely no doubt.
Only regret : the lack of subtitles/little sound imbalance. Sometimes it's difficult to hear the dialogues (audio at 100% on my Oculus Rift S though). It can happen when your interlocutor is far from you or if the action took over. Sometimes also just because I was too concentrate lol. I would have appreciated to be able to have subtitles to catch up. I understand it would have messed up a little bit the HUD and the immersion but i'd have preferred to catch every piece of theses wonderful conversations.

New masterpiece from Ready at Dawn (loved The Order 1886). They work a lot and you can see it at any moment of theirs games.
review_feedback: Hey there! Thanks for sharing your feedback with us. We're happy to hear you loved playing the game :)!

one_reviews_text: The graphics are great and the story line is also what makes it a great game to play, you wont spend no more than 10 minutes max playing though, as it crashes constantly. worth $42.00? To Me, not really only because of the constant crashing in game. My system doesnt crash on the hundreds of AAA games I play, or the other VR titles I play with the Rift S. Hopefully they do a better job with the next version that comes out. Atleast the autosave works, if it wasnt for that, i would have turned this game in for a refund after the first 30 mins. The crashes vary though, i may play 10 or 15 minutes, then it jsut kicks you to the desktop with the splatbug.I sent the first two, but after that, I just quit sending them.

review_title: Best Vr game I ever had.
one_reviews_text: I played many VR games so far and let me tell you... this game is the best VR experience I ever had in my life!!. Graphics,mechanics you guys did amazing job. 100% immersion with the game world, I was a robot you know what I mean ? I wasn't a human anymore while I was playing this game , I was a robot Jack, that's the name my human friend Liv gave me. That was a wonderful experience in space and I can't wait to play Lone Echo II.
review_feedback: Thanks for taking the time to share your feedback with us! We're happy to hear you loved playing Lone Echo and are looking forward to Lone Echo II. :)

review_title: It's EVERYTHING a VR Game should be
one_reviews_text: When I got this, I caught on quick. Easy controls, simple yet intriguing storyline, and realistic animation. I did get somewhat emotionally attatched to the characters. Its a really cool story game where you select your dialogue, making it feel like you're inside a movie! It has mystery, some creepiness, and alot more to really draw you in. This game is really ahead and I hope ALOT more VR games start leaning over in this beautiful immersive storyline style. Basically, if you like an AMAZING storyline, animation, and overall game, get this ASAP. I have never EVER been as exited for a game as I am for Lone Echo 2 :)
review_feedback: Hey there, thanks for sharing your experience with us! We're happy to hear you loved playing the game and are looking forward to Lone Echo II :)

one_reviews_text:
Going to keep it to a few main points.
- The graphics are great. I tend to have high expectations so there were tiny disappointments such as the planet you're staring at not visibly moving but other than that there's no complaints there.
- Movement is great. You can navigate yourself with the thrusters you're equipped with, or you simply grab a wall and push yourself forward. An immense plus for me was that you could turn full movement on, as to also be able to float sideways, upside down, whichever direction you want really. It added that extra bit of realness and considering I'm a space fanatic that was perfect.
- The story itself was decent, and is the main reason why I'm giving this 4 stars instead of 5. A big part of the story consists of you fixing technical difficulties around the ship. There were no real puzzles so there wasn't much of a challenge and the tasks at hand weren't nessecarily the most fun to perform. I wish they had done more with that. 

Either way, I still recommend the game as it's still really well made and overall fun to play. I wish the price tag was a little lower, but when you're playing the game, the production quality says it all.
review_feedback: Thank you for taking the time to share your experience playing Lone Echo with us.

one_reviews_text:
Lone Echo is an amazing journey from beginning to end, even now. Even the bootup sequence at the beginning feels immersive in its own right. Flying through space with thrusters and the ability to pull yourself forward with objects is actually a lot easier to pick up than it sounds. Locomotion is impressively comfortable, but I do strongly suggest getting your VR legs first *before* attempting to play this game.
All in all, an amazing experience. This is as amazing as its competitors, despite not being that new. I can only imagine the reactions of people when this first came out.

review_title: A how to on writing an engaging story
one_reviews_text: Personally, I wanted to play this game the day it released in 2017, but was unable to do so as at that point, VR was much too expensive for me. However thanks to the Oculus Quest and the Link Beta, I was finally able to play this amazing game and it was 100% worth it. It is true that its not the longest game in the world, only taking me about 8 hours to play through the story, but as soon as I finished, I immediately made a new game and began playing through again. I could go on and on about how this game barely made me sick (I've got a bit of a weak VR stomach), or how doing chores had never been more fun, but the TL;DR would just be, I cannot wait for Lone Echo 2 to release!
review_feedback: Thanks for sharing your experience playing Lone Echo on the Quest via the Oculus Link Beta. We're happy to hear you loved playing Lone Echo and are looking forward to Lone Echo II!

review_title: its a battery and generator simulator
one_reviews_text: Visuals are great! I loved all the effects and the game all look great. Game lacks in gameplay. All I found my self doing was grabing things, placing it somewhere and then doing the same thing again. It was super frusterating constantly having to start something by looking for a panel to cut and then attatch something to this and so on. I think most people would enjoy the game. I felt it was dragged on for way too long. Could just be me, was still a fun thing to do during this time!

A captivating story between Captain Olivia Rhodes and her ECHO ONE service droid nicknamed "Jack" as they experience an unusual event while orbiting Saturn in their Kronos II mining station. The story itself is engaging as the mystery unfolds, however the constant (and often humorous) interaction between the two characters is easily one of the highlights of this experience. By the end of their thrilling journey I wanted to experience more adventures with these two.

As for the controls, they remain some of the best in the industry (even almost three years later!) simply because it feels effortless and fun to grab onto surfaces and drift off in zero-gravity. In the course in my eight hour adventure I rarely had an issue with the controls, which couldn't be said about most virtual reality games that I played. Controlling Jack in this game feels natural, even if he is a droid, which is what VR should aim to do in order to help immerse the player even more into the world.

Visually, this game is beautiful. I greatly enjoy outer space, so seeing how huge Saturn looks in virtual reality is nothing short of breathtaking. Environments are visually interesting and have plenty of little details to look at. Even better, most of those little items can be commented on by Jack and Olivia, which helps flesh out the two characters and settings even more. Part of my enjoyment of exploring the space station was just to find things that Jack and Olivia might comment on, which is a testament to the great writing and voice acting of those characters.

Overall, this game is a virtual reality masterpiece. If you've gotten this far into reading, thank you for taking the time to read my review. Please experience Lone Echo and join me as we wait for Lone Echo II to arrive!

VR is meant to let people experience things they never really could; and floating around in zero-g, flinging yourself from area to area, and just being a freakin robot is something Lone Echo nails PERFECTLY. What really entails a perfect VR game is one that can literally pull you into the game, I was even panicking myself during the extremely tense parts. Having this game in your Oculus Library is an achievement in itself and is on par with other amazing titles such as Half-Life Alyx. I will definately keep myself updated for any Lone Echo 2 news and I have no doubt it will join my collection of memorable gaming experiences just like this title has. :)

Lone Echo is one of the first VR games I played. And it's breathtaking. There were so many moments where I just sat there and enjoyed the beatiful view. The story, how you use your tools and interact with others and items is really immersive and awesome!
There are just two little things I would like to see changed in the sequel.
1. When you hold in microgravity onto things and you move your wrist or if you hold with two hands and move them, it would be more realistic if you body and view moved. Then you wouldn't have to turn the camera so often and it would be more immersive.

2. I appreciate your work on how you grab onto things and how each finger works correctly. But this leads to bugging out sometimes. It can be a little frustrating if you grab your objective panel and it just bugs comepletely out. Or if you want to put something in something and it just flys all over the place, because it can't handle the collision.

These are no big game breakers. And the game is still a 9/10, without them it would be a 10/10. 

I just can't wait for the sequel! :)

one_reviews_text: This game starts off slow, and picks up nea- wait, not really. It just stays slow the whole time. Not saying that's a bad thing, but flying around reparing stuff for 4 hours straight really made me want to RACE to just finish this game.  The controls are fine, the game looks amazing, the animations are awesome, voice acting is great - but it's all overshadowed by the constant 'go do this' and 'go do that' and you never get a break. Turn one switch on and then something bad happens to the other switch, go back to turn that switch on and then before you know it you've gone through these mundane chores to find out that something ELSE has gone wrong. When the majority of all you do in this game is press buttons and melt down vents / doors with your tool, it really gets to you. Ontop of that I found myself often getting lost. Constantly figuring out where to go. Not sure if it's just me, but every 15 minutes I had to annoyingly look around because the location to travel to wasn't clear enough I've never really had a problem like this in a game so I feel like I'm being picky complaining about it, but I did find it quite annoying. Hopefully they can do something cool with the second game, cause there's a lot of potential here in my opinon!

one_reviews_text: please

This is by far my best VR experience to date. The graphics and Zero G atmosphere  worked together perfectly to make a super immersive experience. 

I would note this game is not a fast paced action type of game, the focus is more on exploring and figuring out how to repair and move forward in the story. My only real complaint is the saving/checkpoint system. Currently there is no way to manually save the game, which wouldn’t be an issue but the game currently does not tell you when you have hit a checkpoint. So if you are like me and only hop on for an hour or two a night you are playing the guessing game when closing out for the night. I usually just tried to stop after completing a task, I didn’t notice any mid-task checkpoints.

review_title: Great Game Play but lacks essentials
one_reviews_text: I have really enjoyed this game although it isn't as great as the reviews make it sound. I would give it 4 stars overall but one thing just drives me crazy about this game. You can not save the game and it doesn't tell you when you've reached a checkpoint. All VR games should be able to be saved whenever you want because motion sickness can come over you at any time. Almost every time I start this game I have to play the last 5 minutes or more of the last play session. This ruins this game for me because every time I stop playing instead of thinking about all the fun I just had I wonder how much I'm going to have to redo the next time I play. It is just insane to me that they don't give you any indication of save points.  I honestly want to give it one star but the game is better than that. If they add notifications of when its saves or allow you to save whenever you want I will give this game 4 stars but until then I will leave it at 2.

review_title: The best game ever in VR
one_reviews_text: This by far  is the most complete game ever in VR 5 stars

Two things.
1) There is a big when you start with a new body in the transporter you may start stuck in a way you cannot release yourself. There is no menu to let you restart somewhere else or reset your position. Every time this happen your save is gone.
2) I am in this cargo part with the irradiated material, I have no idea how to release it and the radiation keeps forcing me to back away or die in regenerate with the game breaking bug.
Up until now the game was great, but that's what happens when the developer only invest in the starting area of the game.

The big 'WoW' moment for me was the first time i left the ship and floated in space above the rings of Saturn.
That is like a dream come true. You have seen so many pictures maybe animations of Saturn and wondered how it would be beeing there. Well, you get the answer in this game.

The whole time operating in zero gravity (no motion sickness though), some challenging quests but all doable, exciting and touching story and all packed in an amazing looking playground...this game has it all.

Enjoyed it a lot and looking forward for more. Great work guys.

one_reviews_text:
I just finished this game, and I really enjoyed it. I have a Rift-S, which had a couple of glitches, but overall worked wonderfully. The immersion was fantastic, and the graphics were well done, crisp, and clear.

I do get motion sickness, and did experience some discomfort. I found that when I sat down in an office chair that swiveled, and used the thumbstick to alter my view, that most of the negative effects were drastically reduced.

Great storyline, and I enjoyed the tasks. The ending was good, but it felt like a twist was missing, or an additional component that would have been more satisfying. I honestly didn't think Apollo was on the level. And that ship was a ship of war, with little explanation. I would have used those two elements to build more tension.

Overall it was a 4.5 star experience.

one_reviews_text: perfect game for someone like me, the ending was just a little disappointing, but im hyped for the second game already

I am a deafie.

Fantastic game, but one big flaw for me as a deafie -- there is no closed captioning or subtitles.

Many developers read these reviews, and I realize you need to keep ratings high. But other developers (And Oculus Store doesn't have a "Subtitles: Yes"), so I must write this review as a public service to other deaf gamers who need to base buying decisions on subtitles.
 
The best two methods are:
(A) "Republique VR" style in gentle-floating method 
(B) "Red Matter" pipboy style, glance-at-wrist method.

A very clever way to do it is the way Red Matter does it -- wrist mounted caption screen or subtitle screen.     This is superior to floating subtitles/captions, which are not realistic/nauseating in VR.

Real-world deaf people already use an app called "Live Transcribe" on android phones to caption real-life.  So this would just be a VR version of real life.  And there could be a backscroll feature if we miss dialogue, and maybe a "screenglow" effect coming from the bottom edge if we aren't lifting our wrists to read captions -- some of us might understand what's going on but only need to glance at captions when we need to.

Oculus Store gets docked a star because it does not have a "Subtitles: Yes/No" field like SteamVR does. I heard through a friend that some group at Gallaudet University (deaf university) is considering a lawsuit to Oculus to humbly request Oculus to make a minor change to Oculus Store (a Subtitles Yes/No checkbox) to get them to at least tell deaf gamers whether a VR game has subtitles or not.

I am informed the developers will add subtitles to Lone Echo 2.  Kudos to developers for doing this, though it would be nice to retroactively add subtitles.  However, if you are a deaf gamer and require subtitles, this review hopefully informs you accordingly since the Oculus App Store does not have a "Subtitles: Yes" field.
I really enjoyed the game. I really like the story so far, can't wait till part 2 :)

one_reviews_text:
again - the moment when I first played Half-Life.
Lone Echo is absolutely groundbreaking. The immersion is real. The only problem here could be that I develop a video game addiction to this.
Update: So I just finished the game, which is simply perfect: graphics, control, music, sound effects and of course the story! Expecially the ending got me - what a thrill!
BTW: nice touch using Gray/per Time for radiation dosing, and the depiction on how it affects Jack's body!
Though it could be a little bit corrected perhaps: Floating nearby one of those contaminated helium3-containers or being insuside the reaction chamber would give you realistically 300 Gy (or for Olivia as a human being Sv) per hour, or approx 0,1 Gy/sec. 50 or even 300 dGy/s as displayed by the wrist-computer is too much. See
http://imgs.xkcd.com/blag/radiation.png
https://infobeautiful4.s3.amazonaws.com/2011/03/2552_IIB_Radiation-Chart_Feb19.png
So for having a realistic geiger-counter it would display e.g. aboard the Kronos 0.60 to 1.5 µSv/h, outside floating around Saturn 1,5 mSv/h and nearing the dangerous stuff 50, 150, 200 mSv/h. Then very near the dangerous stuff it would show 100 to 1000 Sv/h or Gy/h.
But this is only nitpicking :-)

one_reviews_text:
Really immersive and impressive visuals, but without spoiling anything, at some points in the game, I actually felt like I was working more than anything else. Which could be ok as maybe this is what they are trying to emulate here. 

Moreover, I finished it in 5 hours and was not rushing. I had fun and it was definitely a good experience, but it does depend on the price you are asking for. For this price, I would have expected a more length or an element of replayability. The Arena doesn't count, since it has nothing really to do with the actual game.
review_feedback: Thanks for sharing your honest feedback with us. :]

one_reviews_text:
I enjoyed every minute of this game. The visuals are great, the storytelling is incredible, the pace of the game is very good. It is just an awesome experience. The controls work perfectly. This game is just a must have.
Edit: forgot to mention i can't wait for Lone Echo 2. The story is just too good. Thanks to the developers for this gem.
review_feedback: Thank you for sharing your experience playing Lone Echo. We're happy to hear you enjoyed the game and are looking forward to playing Lone Echo II.

one_reviews_text:
Lone Echo is great! It looks and feels amazing, with very impressive controls and physics. I'm really enjoying the story, but I do wish the puzzles were a bit more challenging, instead of being guided along the whole time. You are told what you need to do and then you explore the immediate area for the item or control panel, etc. There are game like tasks that require you to master the controls a bit which help break up that feeling.

Some of those tasks are navigating corridors while avoiding destructive elements (avoiding spoilers here) or completing multiple tasks within a short time frame. These help add a bit of challenge and break it up from being soley a story experience and a true game experience, but a little more puzzle wouldve been nice to balance everything out. 

I still think this is a must own experience and worth the price (especially if you catch it on sale) because it is truly outstanding, immersive, and engaging. It's possibly the most impressive VR game/experience I've tried and I can't wait for Lone Echo 2!

I originally gave this a poor review due to frustration from an issue with my CPU after an overclock that caused it to crash constantly.  I've sorted the issue (made a seperate overclock profile in BIOS that only uses the MSI gameboost and XMP presets) and now I am enjoying the game at high settings! So I made sure to write up a true review.
review_feedback: Thanks for sharing your feedback with us. Overclocking does cause crashes, however if you fill out our Support Form at http://www.readyatdawn.com/support/ or join the Lone Echo Support Channel in the community Discord, our Devs would be happy to look into the crashes you're experiencing. :) **UPDATE: Glad to hear your issue was resolved and you can enjoy the game!

review_title: Tech Demo, with very mediocre gameplay
one_reviews_text:
I wanted to love this game, because there is everything I like - space, puzzles, interesting locomotion mechanich. Even after few missions I still was excited - but after couple of hours things started getting really boring. Puzzles are absolutely unintuitive and uninspiring, this is definately not Half-Life level. I noticed that I'm forcing myself to play the game. 

For me its clear now why game did not become popular - gameplay is just mediocre.  The only VR game with awesome complete SP experience so far is Boneworks. Hope devs are making a real game with Lone Echo 2 - not just a concept.

I was very deeply immersed into Lone Echo and the only word that came to mind was fantastic.  Unfortunately I then came to the part were you have to beat the clock and dodge the laser beams.  The game then changed from being a experience to a twitch arcade game which doesn't really suit VR games in space, also the game had the cheek to punish you for dying to the laser beam arcade game.  All immersion in the game died along with Jack.

Update:  Once I got past the disappointment of continually dying to a laser beam the game recaptured my interest and I love it.  It would be fantastic to play on flat screen but in VR it is something else.
On a side note, the beat the clock mini games are horrible and I wish there was some way I could mod them out.  Shame they had to dampen the experience with this silliness.  Loses a star.

one_reviews_text:
So you're here willing to know whether you'd spend your money and buy this title. Well, actually yes but read all through this before (it's a short read after all).
I completed the game and I must admit the story is cool. Without going into spoilering details I can tell you you're on a space mission but something goes wrong (of course) and you'll be in charge of sorting all the mess out. Nothing particularly original but it's well executed.
Graphics and sound effects (music there's none) are great and the overall gaming experience is worth it. But.
But keep in mind you're in space and you'll be just moving around clicking this or activating that. If it's action what you're looking for... well, you might consider some other title. This is more about exploring and solving relatively easy puzzles.
Don't get me wrong: I did enjoy it and the overall experience was good, I was just relieved it eventually ended.

review_title: Updated my review to 5 star, here's why
one_reviews_text:
I've changed my review to a 5 star for Lone Echo. It turns out that Lone Echo is very sensitive to overclocked CPUs. My I9-9900k was overclocked to 5GHZ on all cores, and even though it is a stable overclock according to Prime95, there is still that chance as with any overclocked CPU that you will encounter an app or game that doesn't fair well with it. Lone Echo just happened to be that magic number. 

So in essence, I've restored the CPU back to stock speed and the game runs just fine now. Oh well. This is one of those live and learn moments. But this can also serve as a future reference to those who experience issues with Lone Echo or any game that if you encounter freezes or crashes while playing your game, it could be due to an overclock. You know? Us overclockers are pushing our chips beyond the normal specs. So just restore it back to its original state, play your game until your finished, and then you can overclock it again if you choose to.

I want to give a really big shout out and a huge thanks to the supporting staff at Ready at Dawn for jumping into the VR community and making such an awesome game! Lone Echo II will also be in my library on launch day. I highly recommend this one as well to others out there! 

Cheers!
review_feedback: Hey there, thanks for taking the time to share your experience playing Lone Echo so far. If you continue to encounter the bug mentioned, you can fill out our Support form at http://www.readyatdawn.com/support/ or join the Lone Echo Support Channel in the community Discord and our Devs would be happy to help you out. :)

review_title: The Best VR Game I Have Played
one_reviews_text: It is hard to describe the extent to which this game pulls off everything that it sets out to do. The story had me invested the entire length of the game, the graphics are some of the best I have seen in a VR game, and the movement oh the movement. The ability to grab and propel yourself from any surface in zero-G is a joy to play with. I must have spent an hour just floating around the starting area playing with all the little objects that fill it. It has been a long time since the simple act of moving in a game has been this fun. Lone Echo is the gold standard that other games need to strive for and I look forward to what this team delivers next.
review_feedback: Thanks for the love and for sharing your feedback with us!

one_reviews_text:
Lone Echo was the single most enjoyable and immersive VR experience I have ever participated in.  

Through masterful graphic, sound, story, pacing, dialog and environmental design I was transported to another place and became another person.  I started to feel and think and act like Jack as I progressed through the experience.  

Often times when I completed a session I would remove my headset and have to re-adjust to my actual self as I was surprised when I looked down and didn't see an Echo One's hands staring back at me.

Please Note: I played Lone Echo early on in my VR experience (before developing my "VR legs") and suffered ZERO motion sickness.  The locomotion in this game was soothing, satisfying and comfortable.

I am beside myself waiting to continue my experience in Lone Echo 2.  Please hurry Oculus & Ready at Dawn!
review_feedback: Thanks for taking the time to share your feedback! We're happy to hear you loved playing Lone Echo and are looking forward to Lone Echo II :)

one_reviews_text:
I've had my eye on this game for a while and caught it on sale so I thought I'd give it a try.
HOLY COW!  This game is spectacular!
It really sets the bar for an outer space experience.  You're floating weightless the entire time and the way you navigate in this 3D "space" is done very well.  
(Not sure how it would be for those sensative to VR motion sickness though.  I don't have that challenge so I can't judge that aspect.)

Highs:
- Excellent environments/design
- Stunning graphics (ran buttery smooth)
- Spot on physics
- Incredible and compelling story
- Great mix of experiences (slow exploration, tense puzzle solving, humor, awe inspiring environments)

Lows:
- Oculus exclusive; Wish it was on Steam!

If this game sounds even slightly interesting to you, check it out.
You won't be disappointed.
This game is absolutely the best and I can't wait for Lone Echo 2!

Rig: Nvidia GeForce RTX 2070 8G, AMD Ryzen 7 2700X 8-core 3.70Ghz, 16G RAM

After turning on the array, downloading the data and getting the flash charge the game is stuck on downloading the data. I tried loading and replaying the mission again but got stuck again with the same issue - cannot proceed. I did get this game on launch and just starting playing again. So perhaps there is an issue with old save files which got messed up with an update? 

I gave this a great review for the gameplay I did experience. I uninstalled it for now. If this gets fixed I will continue playing.

Thanks and hope this gets addressed!

Edit: Thanks for the response, will give this a shot!

Update: I got the save file and was able to replay the mission, and this time was able to progress. I'm now further in the game - thanks!

Update: Just finished it - awesome!!

review_title: One of the best VR experiences

It strongly leverages the features and functionalities of VR, and ties all that into the gameplay of an immersive space adventure. The movements and controls feel very natural to perform in no time. Visually impressive, although the limitations of VR graphics (aliasing, loss of detail on distant objects, etc) are still present. Suitable for gamers of all levels.

one_reviews_text:
When we did Mission Critical in 94 @ Legend Entertainment (with the the old Infocomm crew), we were creating games for 386's and 486's. We could not imagine having the opportunity to create something like this. It was unheard of. 2+hrs to render 1 frame for a cut scene back then (not even compositing). We were hand coding x86 to squeeze clock cycles out of those old boxes.

I enjoyed the heck out of the immersive levels, the mechanics (motion), the user input system, 3d models, leve ldesign. The touches like the dynamic textures were done very tastefully. The dev team should take a victory lap, this was very well done.

If you enjoy adventure games, or are wondering where to start with a new Oculus, this should be a very strong consideration. It is a great showcase for what is possible with this system.

one_reviews_text:
I can see why people like Lone Echo, it's a new locomotion to show off VR, coupled with decent graphics, animations, physics and voice acting.  It's also at a high bug-free quality that ran well with 4xAA, no TXAA (horrid blur with that on) and everything else on its highest.  

The problem is that it quickly gets boring, and I had to push myself to allow the story to develop.  Then it got boring again just doing the same sort of thing over and over whilst being ordered around by anything you interact with.

For me, it sits somewhere between a technical demonstration of VR (this is good) and a very average game at best.  I never felt challenged and the penalty for dying (or whatever you'd call it in Lone Echo) is practically non-existent, and the method of respawning seems to destroy all believabilty.  

I am sure it was well recieved when it was released, and if you're venturing into VR then you'll appreciate it for the VR aspect (it's a family friendly game), for others, it's a 3-4 stars IMO.  I give it 3.5, and hope its sequel has a little more depth now that they have a polished engine and all the Lone Echo mechanics to build on.

review_title: A must buy game for every VR-set owner
one_reviews_text:
Let's get one thing straight, I am a huge junkie for Sci-Fi and Space games; Ever since I saw the Alien films and played AVP:2 back in the day of potato PCs. So my review and experience with the game is affected by that.

I will try to keep spoilers to absolute minimun, only keeping some very minor details or things seen in the trailers in the review.

Some small details to set the review up:

The game sets on a station orbiting Saturn in the future, you're controlling the only "intelligent" and "aware" robot in the station but don't worry, the captain of the station and the only human in it: Olivia Rhodes resides in it with other robots who mostly are made to maintain the station. In the first minutes of the game after the tutorial, and after getting to know Olivia a bit, you're greeted to this BREATHTAKING view of the saturns orbit from the bridge window; shortly after this a blast of somesort happens, messing up the station and it's robotics, including you a bit; an anomaly appears near the station orbiting the planet, giving you a target and the reason to continue this adventure that you just started. 

Now to more basic stuff:

The game is in space, so with no gravity you use the enviroment to pull yourself forward, later you get a booster pack to help you spacewalk when you finally get to traverse the exterior of the station.

The art & Graphics

This game is beautiful, there is really no place to find where it looks low-poly, badly rendered or just ugly, every place in the game is brimming with detail and love that went into this game, and the space setting just is a topping on the cake here.

Story

Lone Echo almost instantly gives you a reason to keep going, never swaying away with bad writing or dialogue. The game just keeps giving more reasons to keep interest in it, at this time of review..I think I spent most of my playtime my mouth open because how immersed and cool it was to play through.

Performance

Ran smooth and no bugs, with a 2080ti & i7-8700k

This game was possibly the MOST Immersive experience I have had yet! with the way the movement system feels so natural and the great visuals and story its becomes a huge bundle of robotic love! After finishing the game I couldnt help but think: "Wait, What do I do with my life now?" This game kept me entertained the whole way. (SPOILER ALERT)  
When Olivia Lost conciousnes on the future ship bridge, And I was shocking her trying to revive her, I was actually starting to be worried. I felt emotion, more emotion than most other games ever give me. and my happiness when she came around was beyond belief.
(End Spoiler)
Its a suspensful, Immsersive, and Even heart warming story of two characters. 
Echo-1 (or as he is called: Jack) and Captain Olivia Rhodes. You are Echo 1, the only sufficient company for Olivia, nicknamed "Liv". The other bots, labor Bots, Arent as....socially adanced as your model. the witty humor, amazing character development and the noticeable friendship between Bot and Human makes these two chacracters instantaneously likeable. My only wish is for some DLC! (Spolier!)
What happens to the two after arriving in the future? Do they ever get back to their time? What about Apollo? Who attacked the future ship? what exactly WAS that bio weapon!?
(spoiler end)
Thats my ten cents on Lone Echo. My Optical servos are on the lookout for DLC or even Lone Echo 2!

Edit: The Anomaly seems to be disrupting my servos, Guess Ill just scan the Kronos-II databases for Lone Echo 2/DLC. Darn spatial fluctuations.

one_reviews_text:
Ok, after trying everything but the kitchen sink, I finally got the game to work properly.. Aparently, although it doesn't say so anywhere that I've seen, the game has a thing about multiple sensors and certain usb ports..
Now that it's working properly, the game is a real beauty. I give it 4/5 because you can't rotate using hand grips in zero-g, which is a bit counterintuitive. Maybe an idea for the next update..
Anyhow, here's what you need to know, for anyone who has the same problems I had: the game doesn't work with more than two sensors connected. If you have 3 or more (like me), disconnect them prior to entering the game. Also, if both of the remaining sensors are connected to usb 3.0 (even on different controllers), you get motion glitches. So just connect one of them to a usb 2.0 port and voila..you can finally play the game.
A note to the devs: i'd suggest you either fix it so the game works with more than two sensors, or make a note in the game description that the game requires a maximum of 2 sensors connected..

review_title: In space no one can hear you sigh.
one_reviews_text:
Space waifu / blue collar spaceman sim Lone Echo is the pinnacle of opulence in VR. You can't fault the graphics and it's fairly obvious that what Oculus Studios were gunning for here was something that pushed the visual spectacle of VR to the current limit. They succeeded - the rendering and staging of this are probably Oscar worthy (seeing as the film Gravity won a few Oscars and this is essentially Gravity in VR).

So you're in space with a lovely British space lass with characteristically dry humour (she really was well written, voiced and looked absolutely amazing btw) - but what's a space robot to do? Well, as it turns out we're fixing a bunch of dodgy equipment by plugging things in and switching things on as per continuous instruction, followed by a second act of dodging space boogers. 

Now I have to admit here, I am not a very clever person. In terms of engineering skills, I struggle with the photocopier at work. But were these really puzzles or just menial tasks? I felt less like a quadruple digit IQ robo astronaut than a 12 year old on an apprenticeship at a Duplo factory. There was no challenge here, or maybe I've been playing these silly games too long. I would have preferred a more involved engineering challenge - maybe fitting those pieces of equipment together into a neat box in the right order would have been a good one. I struggle to see how the devs couldn't think of interesting challenges here - just watch some re-runs of the Crystal Maze and copy all those puzzles!

Then we go into some big, doomed super spaceship and deal with the satanic alien snot/booger dichotomy. This wasn't a terrible idea but somehow I rather liked the earlier staging without the aliens, it felt more real and by invoking the space snot, things felt less real and more like a game - except there wasn't much gaming to be had apart from those ever demanding switches.

So for Lone Echo 2 - more story, harder puzzles, more human characters, less boogers, please.
review_feedback: Hey there! Thanks for taking the time to share your honest feedback with us.

one_reviews_text: I dont know if anyone else has made this comparison before, but I would compare Lone Echo to Half Life. This is truely a breakthrough in story telling, just like half life was for its time. Everything about this game has been meticulously crafted, the graphics - the character details, Liv's facial details like her wrinkles, teeth, hair are life-like. The directional surround sound effects and music sets the atmosphere perfectly, the movement and controls simulate the feeling of floating in space, the story is well written and directed with mystery, action, suspence. Lone Echo is simply the best single player gaming experience right now, even after over a year since its release no other game can compare to this quality. It has taken me this long to write this review even though I bought the game when it first released, because I wanted to play this game at its highest quality settings and running at 90FPS. review_title: Ever wanted to go to space? Try this!
one_reviews_text:
So I'm late to the VR party, getting the Rift S as my first headset. I was hesitating buying this game. Just price-wise and the "longevity" of other VR titles are somewhat short when i comes to singleplayer experience. 

This is far from short. I finished the game i 7 hours, and i believe i could have explored far more than i did initially.  This is a take your time kinda a game all sorts of things to see.

You play as an Echo-Unit, a human-like helper-robot aboard a ship accompanied by Captain, Olivia.  You're equipped with various tools at your disposal to solve problems and fix and ivestigate. 

Its a refreshing game, and quite different in that you wont shoot or harm anything or anyone.  I especially like this because instead of being another space shooter type game, its heavly focused on puzzle solving, investigating and communication. And they've managed to not make it repetitive as well.

Clever use of VR mechanics, levers, objects and navigation. It becomes second nature as soon as you get used to the controls. 

Try it, you wont regret it.

one_reviews_text: Lone Echo is by far the best VR game I've ever played. Many single player VR games are fun but lack in story. They have about an hour's worth of gameplay for the most part. Lone Echo on the other hand has hours worth of gameplay, each hour far more exciting than the last. review_title: It's ok, but not much more
one_reviews_text:
Lone Echo has two things going for it, a good control scheme and a nice presentation. The zero-g controls managed to give a good amount of freedom, without even a hint of motion sickness. Being limited to stick rotation and not having an option for two-handed grab rotation felt a little limited in the beginning, but one gets used to that. The presentation is quite nice, especially early when interacting a lot with Olivia.

On the downside is that this game doesn't really have much more to offer. All the cutting and holo minigames feel like taken straight out of Wii's Metroid Prime 3 and get quite repetitive. The rest of the gameplay boils down to fetch quests which get just as repetitive and leave little room for agency or exploration. The later half of the game also gets much less interesting, as most of it is spend separated from Olivia and moving slowly and carefully through dark and uninteresting corridors.

As for the story, well, there really isn't much of a story. You are on a space station and encounter a problem and than you deal with that problem, that's it. It all feels a little to straight forward and more like the first act of a larger story, than a whole story in itself. It's not bad, but it completely relies on the banter between Olivia and Jack, while everything else is just backdrop that never gets explored in depth.

All in all, it's fine, it doesn't do anything too offensively bad, while laying a solid ground work that a sequel can expand upon.
review_feedback: Hey there! Thanks for taking the time to share your honest feedback with us

review_title: Great use of VR. But is it a great game?
one_reviews_text:
What's Good:

Movement Mechanics:  Grab and hold, push off to move, glide in weightlessness; super.  It's identical to Mission:ISS, which is pretty fantastic if you haven't tried it.

Interface:  In addition to movement, visor up and down (although that doesn't seem to impact the game in any way), activate and deactivate a Holographic PDA and Cutting Tool, are all done extremely well, using wrist-buttons; point to your own wrists, or your head to activate / deactivate.  Well done.

Ambience:  There's a Zen to the game as you play.  You can take as long as you like exploring the set-pieces, and there is a decent amount of stuff to discover.

Interesting characters:  Jack and Liv are likeable.

What's Bad:

Inconsequential Dialogue:  These have zero impact on the game's outcome, so conversation reply choices are superfluous.

Tedious Sections:  There are points in the game where navigation through very narrow, fatal, hot-spots is required.  These are absolutely annoying, frustrating, and only serve to artificially lengthen play-time.  There's another section which has you fly around on a timer, without clear navigational tools.  Hopefully the developers do away with these gimmicks in sequels.

Far Too Short:  Aside from the "hot-spots" and "do this before time runs out" issues mentioned to lengthen the game, there's not much here content wise.  Yes, it's a neat world they've created.  Yet without the tedious bits, the game's run-time would be very, very short.

Overall:

The game makes excellent use of VR controls and visuals, but strip those away and the game falls pretty short of the title of "a great game."  It's the VR visuals and controls that shine here, yet it's let down by the fact that the game is short, dialogue is tacked on without any consequences, and it's marred by the fly through killer hot-spots and timed sequences ... which are absolutely annoying.

Hopefully the next installments turn this into a good game in its own right, and not because it's VR.

review_title: The way 5 stars games look like
one_reviews_text:
Well to be honest this is the best VR game we have at the moment.
You play as robot on the space station and space. You doing tasks, explore surrondings and take part in interesting story line. If you not hurry and like to explore you get 20+ hours of playing.
You will not find shooter here (absolutely ;) ), it's story-based adventure with no guns and zombies and bad space guys.

+++
- Great graphics and models
- Strong atmosphere
- Very high immersive
- Perfect touch pads realization
- Interesting game mechanics good utilize VR and touch pads potential
- High quality in-game training system (you never have questions "how to...")
- Interesting and sometimes exciting story
- Intuitive usefull interface

- - -
- Not high replayability
- No achievements
- No russian language (for me personally) or english subtitles at least to understand speaking easily
- Found few minor bugs

I strongly recommend to buy this game not matter what kind of game genres you prefer (me personally love shooters) because you just can't miss this experience. Don't wait a discount - i waited long enough (and didn't get any discount eventually) and i so regret i hold myself from this experience for long time. This game costs every dollar you pay for it.
Special thanks to Oculus studio for the game. Can't wait next part.

Ok. I get it. My title makes no sense. But once you play this game, it will. 

Lone Echo is an amazing experience. The freedom of movement in zero G is pulled off so convincingly that it alone is worth the price of admission. And that’s before factoring in the great graphics, story, voice acting and more. 

But Lone Echo is also a flawed game. It has an ending that is equal parts finished and clearly set for a sequel. It lacks variety in its gameplay. And I experience a fair share of bugs. 

Despite some fairly serious gripes, I was captivated by the main characters, fully immersed in the world, and immediately revisited an old save just to explore and find collectibles (something I NEVER do in games) right after the credits rolled. 

More so than any other game I’ve played before, Lone Echo is a perfect game with plenty of flaws. It’s a must play for Oculus and VR owners.

review_title: Most immersive game for me so far
one_reviews_text:
-- Motion Sickness
I'm usually pretty sensitive in regards to motion sickness but in this case I have experienced nearly nothing.
However, I use 360 tracking and that might be factor (this means I just turn around naturally / without using the sticks).

-- Controls
The movement system is just incredible and the introduction of all controls is very well made.
In the beginning it was fun just floating around. Later in the game it is required to steer precisely through space. But that was - at least in my case - no problem since you have enough time to learn everything.

-- Graphics & Audio
The visuals are detailed and the game looks nice. I use a Rift S with a Nvidia GTX 1080 and had no framerate related problems.
Audio fits to the scenario. There is no music (as far as I can remember) and you just hear your surroundings.

-- Story
I believe it is a decent storyline even for non SciFi lovers. Including some surprising "wtf is going on" moments.
If you are into the genre, then you will ask yourself the whole time about the backgrounds which can also be pretty fun.

-- Conclusion
All parts of the game fit together. The scenario, the controls and the visuals.
This is currently my favourite VR game.
Lots of love went into this game, its all in the details. It's one of the best VR titles on the market. Buy it ... trust me' everyone else has :P

But the game is really awesome. Its pricy for its 5 hours playtime but it felt like 10 hours. VR is well done, no motion sickness.
The devs deserve the support and every Cent. Thats how you do a VR game! Lone Echo 2 can come :)

review_title: Good Quality, Short Game for Price
one_reviews_text: Let me start by saying the game was good but when I pay $45 I expect the content to last more than a couple hours. A lot of the tasks became redundant though but the storyline and micro-gravity experience was nice. If you consider this game you have to ask yourself if $15 per hour of content is worth it. I'm new to Rift S as of May 2019 and this was the first game I got.  I've been waiting since the first Tron movie and Lawnmower man for this level of VR.  The motion is easy to learn and the details are perfect.  This is the benchmark...that is at least untl Stormland comes out.

That must be what 'AAA' quality games mean, because this IS the expereince that sets the standard.  Of the 40+ VR experiences and games that I have this one is absoluely TOP of the list.  Took me about 9 hours to complete (Yes I was totally engrossed ) but there's plenty of scope (for me) to go back in to complete more of secondary mission objectives and just take in the breathtaking graphics (system specs below).  I was quite clumsy getting about at first but that sorted it self out when i got my space legs.

Its a game.  No its a story!  No its a VR extravangaza!  No its all of these and much more.  I haven't seen such a quality interaction with game characters before, all of the rendering is hard shelled, there's no poking your head through walls and the physics in  terms of action items has a perfectly natural feel.

I waited an age to buy this because of its price, but its by far the best game out here for Rift.  I cant' wait for Lone Echo II.

The gameplay has its moments of tension nicely fettered with reasonably thought provoking puzzle  elements and exploration.  As mentioned, there are optional missions which I ignored first time around but I will go back for them.

My Best VR game buy to date, that will be untill Lone Echo II no doubt!

System Specs
i7 4790, 16gb RAM, Zotac Mini 1070Ti,
I ran everything on Max'd out graphics which gave me some slight (intermittent) motion jerkyiness but not to the point I needed to change anything, nope not at all!
I want the second one so bad cause this is one of my top 5 games you must have if you own a rift
This is why VR exists...

This is by far the best VR game out there. It's the only one I've played that uses the Touch controller, the environment and the way you move to really put you in the world. Or ship, to be more exact about it.

The game is full of "oh, wow" moments, from the first time you look out at Saturn from the ship's bridge, to the simple act of pulling the scan panel out from your wrist scanner, to zero-g monkey-barring through the stations rooms and crawlspaces. It's all done with such attention to detail and consistency that you find yourself totally immersed in the situation. 

The station is well designed and feels authentic, and Olivia, the only human crewmember is well acted and animated. Watching her navigate around the station, it's easy to forget she's just an animated character in a video game. 

The zero-G physics are great too - you really do feel like you're floating around. When you have to pull a lever or pump a handle, you've got to grab onto something else so you can the leverage. It's all things you don't really think about when you think about zero-G environments, but it makes perfect sense when you're in the game.

I only have a couple of criticisms - one is that you get so immersed in the game that it's easy to turn yourself round and lose tracking. It's not a big deal (and not a deal at all if you've got a 360 setup), but it does take you out of the experience a bit when your arm is flickering between a couple of positions that have no relation to your actual arm. The other criticism is equally minor; to open your visor and switch on your headtorch, you have to press a button on either side of your helmet, but there's no indication where the buttons are supposed to be (they're on the bottom curves of your headset), but once you've found them you're good to go. 

Those minor gripes aside, the experience is otherwise flawless. This is VR as VR should be. I hope it sets the standard for other triple-A VR games to follow.
the history is cool it will be more coll if they can put multiplater history this game is amazing it is like echo but no multiplayer

Lone Echo is a stunning example of what can be accomplished with virtual reality. The visuals are jaw-dropping, the story is confusing in the best way, it makes you think hard. One of the best traits is that it doesn't lack content. Lots of great games built from the ground up for vr are 1 or 2 hours long (looking at you, Red Matter.) This game maneages to pack in 6 or 7 hours of intriguing and unique gameplay (you can even get a few more hours of gameplay if you complete all the optional tasks.) Last of all, the mechanics are great. Anything you can see you can pick up or propel off of. I was debating with myself whether I should get the game and I finally decided I would. Now that I've played it, I dare say Lone Echo might be the best vr game I've ever played. (coming from a person who has played lots of vr games.) So anybody like me, reading this wondering if they should get Lone Echo... Trust me, you won't regret it.


Side note: I'm seeing lots of comments talking about performance issues at certain parts of the game (particularly when you leave the space station.) I had the same problem. At that part of the game I noticed how bad my character's shadow looked and I went to turn up the graphics quality. I cranked it right up to max, (which almost always works for games on my computer.) And the frames dropped significantly. It worked at medium with standard resolution, but if you are experiencing problems, turn it down for that section.
Just wow, go in totally blind and just play it. never have I ever cared so much for a character in a video game!

review_title: Exactly what VR gaming should be
one_reviews_text:
This is a highly polished, immersive, story driven single player game that really does transport you into a zero gravity outer space future.  It's a legitimate masterpiece that is worth paying the full price for, and this is coming from someone who sets his watch by Steam sales.

This is one of those games that truly gives you new 'wow' moments and experiences, and I've played loads of VR games now.

As engaging as it is entertaining, this is a VR game that simply MUST be in every VR gamers library. and completed!

review_title: By far the best Oculus game I've played
one_reviews_text:
I picked this up pretty early on after buying an Oculus Rift and, as soon as I started playing it, I stuck with it and ignored every other game I had for about a week. Everything about this game is pretty much perfect and I'm looking forward to the sequel a LOT.

The story is interesting and intriguing, with decent voice acting and sound design to back it up, and very pretty graphics. The gameplay has been designed carefully with VR fully in mind and is both really enjoyable and challenging, with some really well thought-out puzzles.

Even though you're able to turn with the analog stick, I'd really recommend a 360° set up for this game, as it's so engrossing that you tend to physically turn around a lot without realising (or I did, at least).

review_title: This... is what I expected from VR
one_reviews_text:
Let me start by saying I am very nit-picky.  And cheap.  I want the absolute most bang from my buck.  I had very high expectations when I bought my Oculus, and because of my high expectations, I have been dissapointed by many experiences that are out there.  Many just rushed to get a game out so the developers can say they are developing VR experiences.  Bad locomotion, horrible performance, clunky mechanics, or thin plots... there are a lot of them out there.

I read the reviews on this game, and felt that it was worth the try.  I feel that RPG experiences like this is where VR really sets itself apart from regular gaming.  

I was absolutley blown away from the begining.

The visuals... the sound (classical music playing in the background for a very Stanley Kubrick - Space Odyssey touch is perfect!), the mechanics, the story line... this experience (this is so much more than a game) is absolutley incredible.  The locomotion is absolutley brilliant... it truly makes you feel weightless.  

The cool part... is the little things like touching your arm to engage your plasma cutter... or touching the top of your hand to watch the scanner engage.  It's like being in an Iron Man suit lol.

This is very much so worth the money.  I really can't anything wrong with it.  If you're on the fench about buying it... do it.  You'll come to appreciate VR much more so once you do.  I know I did.

Since getting the Rift a few months ago I kept hearing this was THE killer app, and it lived up to all my expectations! Great pacing, perfect length for a VR game, engaging story and characters I grew fond of and really cared about. Fantastic job, RAD should be proud of their work. Lone Echo 2 will be a day one purchase for me!!!

This is by far the best VR game i have played to date, by a long shot. Characters are super realistic and loveable, gameplay isnt too repetitive including a good mixture of puzzles at casual difficulty, player interation is perfect. I had a true sense of exploration, it was a little spooky at times and held suspense. This is the most visually satisfying game i have ever played on any gaming platform. There were zero bugs/glitches throughout gameplay. It took me about 4.5 hours to complete. I cannot wait for Lone Echo 2!

Thanks

one_reviews_text: It begins very well, and it could have been great if that beginning part was longer, but the main part has rather unimaginative, repetitive scenery, and it's not challenging at all - really more of an experience than a game. A longer game with more of the space station, and perhaps more open with more things to do would be amazing, but it really started to get boring. The game mechanics feel great, but I don't think it lived up to its potential.

Thise game is so beutifull! I play everything om max and it runs smooth :), What a game is thise! its incredible, all the details, the props, the story.... you get sucked into the game :) Deffently worth the price tag!

review_title: Literally the best VR game ever!
one_reviews_text: Pretty much everything in this game is interactive, which is really awesome and really shows the effort Ready At Dawn put into this game. Definately a AAA game made for VR! Olivia Rhodes is extremely responsive and I feel kinda weird for admitting that I love her, but hopefully after playing this game you would understand ;) If you're gonna have a relationship with a videogame character, out of all of them, I think Olivia Rhodes is the best... Okay, but that aside, the entire game is amazing. Can't wait for Lone Echo 2. In fact, although after a while I began to think this game had no replayability, because the story is so involved, I have decided to replay it and I soon got right back into the groove. Definately recommended!

review_title: The best story single player VR game
one_reviews_text: This is hands down the best VR sp game. 8-10 hours of AAA vr experience. Must have for all VR gamers

Took a break, and much to my dismay the game now attemps to launch, and crashes instantly. There is no blug splat error, there is no error message, just a brief white window and immediate crash.

This is an amazing game. congratulations  Lone Echo team.
Just completed it amazing game well done

review_title: Probably the best VR game ever
one_reviews_text: This is the main reason I bought an Oculus Rift, and I have to admit, it delivered the SCI-FI experience I was hoping for. Amazing game!
review_feedback: Thanks for your feedback!

This is exactly what VR was made for. You truly feel like you are floating in space. The movement is smooth and intuitive. The story and acting are top notch. Can't recommend higly enough; definitely worth paying full price for.

review_title: The best VR game. No kidding.
one_reviews_text: I couldn't get enough and wish they had DLC with different scenarios. I mean this game engine is one of the best. I wouldn't mind add-on contents and extra side missions. Those are my only complaints about it.

I've spent dozens of hours in this game and I love it so much. The zero-g movement mechanics are absolutely breath taking and I enjoy them every time I pick the game back up. I really really wish more games like Lone Echo were available for Oculus.

I think most of the 5 star reviews are from people new to VR and are more blown away by vr then by the game. It is one of the best looking VR games at the moment but "game" I use generously. It is more of an interactive story. Basic fetch quests and flying from point to point is pretty weak gameplay. No replayablility. Overpriced. VR implemented well from an immersion standpoint.
